update.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
update.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion

content.raw:
~~The new test `EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(1.0, 1e9 * IGN_NANO_TO_SEC);` should verify that `IGN_SEC_TO_NANO` is correct, so that seems fine to me.~~

Never mind, it's `EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(nsec, IGN_SEC_TO_NANO * sec);` that should verify it. Still, seems fine.
content.html:
The new test EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(1.0, 1e9 * IGN_NANO_TO_SEC); should verify that IGN_SEC_TO_NANO is correct, so that seems fine to me.

Never mind, it's EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(nsec, IGN_SEC_TO_NANO * sec); that should verify it. Still, seems fine.

content.raw: That's a good idea but I'd leave that small refactor for a separate pull request as is a separate issue if you agree.
content.html: That's a good idea but I'd leave that small refactor for a separate pull request as is a separate issue if you agree.

update.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
update.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion

content.raw:
I'm guessing that the trailing digits on the significands of these floating point literals are meant to deal with floating point imprecision. However, the `EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ` macro should already take care of that for us.

I recommend that we put the exact value that we expect in these test expressions, and allow the macro to take care of the floating point complications.

I made a commit to take care of this: 5df7f6b Feel free to merge that if it looks good. I verified that the test still passes with those changes on my machine.
content.html:
I'm guessing that the trailing digits on the significands of these floating point literals are meant to deal with floating point imprecision. However, the EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ macro should already take care of that for us.

I recommend that we put the exact value that we expect in these test expressions, and allow the macro to take care of the floating point complications.

I made a commit to take care of this: 5df7f6b Feel free to merge that if it looks good. I verified that the test still passes with those changes on my machine.

content.raw: Agreed, but we should keep the scope of this PR as small as possible.
content.html: Agreed, but we should keep the scope of this PR as small as possible.

content.raw:
This seems really bizarre to me. What does it mean to divide a time value by another time value? In the best case scenario, it seems like it should produce a unitless ratio of durations (i.e. a scalar floating point value), not a new time value.

I guess this can't really be removed since it's already part of the public API, but we should consider deprecating it unless we have a compelling motivation or a meaningful concept behind it. Although we might want to consider deprecating all of the `Time` classes in favor of `std::chrono`.
content.html:
This seems really bizarre to me. What does it mean to divide a time value by another time value? In the best case scenario, it seems like it should produce a unitless ratio of durations (i.e. a scalar floating point value), not a new time value.

I guess this can't really be removed since it's already part of the public API, but we should consider deprecating it unless we have a compelling motivation or a meaningful concept behind it. Although we might want to consider deprecating all of the Time classes in favor of std::chrono.

content.raw:
Another option is to set them to `static_cast<int>(1e9)`. That would give us the best of both worlds.

Also I'd suggest making them `const int` instead of using `#define`.
content.html:
Another option is to set them to static_cast<int>(1e9). That would give us the best of both worlds.

Also I'd suggest making them const int instead of using #define.

update.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
update.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion

update.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. I replaced the literals with e-notation for avoid similar issues in the future. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
update.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion

content.html: I restored *_TO_NANO just in case. 3f58d97

update.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. I replaced the literals with e-notation for avoid similar issues in the future. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
update.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion

content.raw:
using `1e-9` definitely makes sense for `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC`

there could be some type issues with the `*_TO_NANO` variables though, since this PR changes them from integer constants to floating point constants
content.html:
using 1e-9 definitely makes sense for IGN_NANO_TO_SEC

there could be some type issues with the *_TO_NANO variables though, since this PR changes them from integer constants to floating point constants
